journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: Vehicle strip element in the analysis of stiffened plate under realistic moving loading

article-meta.aff: Department of Computer Modeling, University of Rijeka, Rijeka, Croatia

author-notes.corresp: Ivica Kozar, Department of Computer Modeling, Faculty of Civil Engineering, University of Rijeka, Rijeka 51000, Croatia. Email: ivicak@gradri.hr

abstract.p: In this article, a new vehicle strip element is proposed for a vehicle–bridge interaction modelling. Finite strip method principle is applied on the vehicle dynamic system in order to model and couple vehicle with the structure, which is discretised with flat shell strip elements. Vehicle degrees of freedom are transformed and embedded into the structural ones, such that any new conditions or model changes can be easily integrated. Combined with the shell finite strip it enabled observing all degrees of freedom of the structure and the vehicle, reducing modelling and calculation time and effort in the same time. A full vertical vehicle model with nine degrees of freedom is adopted here. The bridge is modelled as a simply supported stiffened plate with use of a flat shell strip elements. The main benefit of the vehicle strip element is possibility to analyse vehicle–structure interaction in a greater detail. This resulted in more realistic and comprehensive analysis of a bridge under the moving loading. Such realistic examples of bridge analysis are rare in literature due to the large effort they require using standard finite elements. A parametric study is made to compare the vehicle models with different level of complexity and to enquire the relationship between model simplification and the reliability of results. In contrast to beam or plate models, application of the flat shell strip element enabled the analysis with the realistic bridge cross section.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structure-vehicle interactions are often investigated for purposes such as structure design, maintenance and driver safety and comfort. In many studies, either the structure or the vehicle is highly simplified in the analysis. In majority of the previous papers, moving loading was usually modelled as a concentrated force that changes its position in space and time, depending on the moving velocity; or as a moving series of forces on the fixed distance.1–4 This sort of idealisation neglects vehicle dynamic properties entirely. When it comes to flexible structures, such as bridges, vehicles can have mass comparable to the structure mass and, therefore, should not be neglected.5–8 Some authors treated vehicle mass as a continuous mass.6,9 However, vehicle mass is concentrated and with change of its position, inertial properties and excitation of the structure vary greatly. Beside the mass, vehicle stiffness in the form of elastic spring is introduced.2,10 Drawback of this model was that the entire vehicle loading was transmitted through the single contact point. When dealing with a heavy vehicle with a few axles, such as truck or a semi-trailer, more appropriate way for vehicle modelling is a separate dynamic system based on the concentrated masses connected with springs and dashpots.2,11 In recent years, vehicle is usually presented with a half car model (pitch and bounce vehicle model),12,13 or a full vehicle model.14,15 Structure is usually modelled as a beam5,6,16,17 or a plate12–15 with different boundary conditions. Influence of the bridge cross section could not be observed with these simplified structure models. In numerical analysis of the structure, discretisation is usually performed with a finite element method1,7 or some special cases of finite element method.11

However, dynamic influence of the vehicle motion on the structure does not endanger its bearing capacity, but systematically degrades its serviceability and a lifetime. Hence, it is important to study and to be familiar with the structure behaviour under the influence of moving loading, as well as the influence of various factors of the structure-vehicle interaction, especially being aware of the trend of building light structures and an increase of heavy traffic. Modelling of a complete structure with associated traffic is a very demanding assignment. An enough detailed and realistic vehicle and structure model with use of the standard techniques for analysis such as classic finite element method would be very bulky and time consuming. This is the reason why the structure model, as well as the vehicle model, is usually very simplified.

The main intention of this study is to apply finite strip element method on the vehicle dynamic system, which should provide analysis of a realistic spatial structure with reliable and complex vehicle model. Vehicle strip element enables separating and observing just the contact points of the structure and the vehicle and adequate degrees of freedom (DOFs). A parametric study is made to compare vehicle models with different level of complexity, in order to enquire in what extent simplification of the model affects the reliability of analysis results. The intension is also to investigate the importance of the bridge cross-section shape and stiffness in the vehicle–bridge interaction modelling, which was not possible with a beam and a plate structure model. The use of the finite strip and vehicle strip element method should reduce the number of unknowns to the great extent and provides less computational time and effort.

sec.title: Moving force
sec.p: A moving load is basically an impulse loading, that varies in time and space and depends on the moving velocity. A moving force can be represented by the Dirac impulse function using the Kronecker δ operator in the form δ(x − v0t). Because of use of the finite strip elements based on a series expansion, the loading must be converted into an acceptable form. In the finite strip method, the impulse loading is implemented such that the concentrated force is also expanded into a series and then multiplied by the longitudinal and transverse finite strip shape functions. Dynamic equation for a plate under a moving force18 (1)ρh∂2w(x,y,t)∂t2 +D(∂4w(x,y,t)∂x4+2∂4w(x,y,t)∂x2∂y2+∂4w(x,y,t)∂y4) =F(t)δ(x-ξ)δ(y-v·t)

sec.title: Vehicle model with five DOFs
sec.p:
The wheel forces depend on the vertical motion of a vehicle mass (bouncing) z and rotation around horizontal axis (pitch) θ. Equations of motion for a vehicle model with n DOFs can be written as (2)Mv·z··+∑i=1nki(z-zik+θ(yv-yi))=-Mvg (3)Iθ·θ··+∑i=1nki(z-zik+θ(yv-yi))(yv-yi)=0 (4)mik·z··ik-ki(z-zik+θ(yv-yi))=kik·z0i where n DOFs concerns pitch and bounce vehicle model with n number of springs. Pitch and bounce vehicle model, with three springs in a series and five DOFs, is observed here (Figure 1). System of differential equations adequate for a five-DOF model is given in the Appendix 2. Figure 1.
Five-DOF vehicle model. DOF: degree of freedom.

sec.title: Vehicle model with nine DOFs
sec.p:
This model can be named a full vertical vehicle model, since it observes all types of a vehicle motion in the vertical plane. In this vehicle model the centre of mass has three DOFs: bounce, roll and pitch, while each wheel has only one bounce (Figure 2). Rolling is a consequence of the front and back axle interference. Moment of inertia of the vehicle, with respect to imaginary transverse axis, prevents front and back suspension loading from being equal and constant on uneven surfaces. Thus, vehicle dynamic influence on the structure is reduced. Pitching effect is actually a rotation of the vehicle around the longitudinal axis through the centre of gravity. Moment of inertia of the vehicle with respect to longitudinal axis ensures such loading distribution between left and right wheels, to avoid vehicle turning over sideways. Figure 2.
Three-axle vehicle idealisation.

In the purpose of simplification, some assumptions are introduced: vehicle is observed as a single rigid body and there is no loss of contact between the wheel and the ground. Constant contact is ensured through the contact force, which is the same for the vehicle and the structure. Equations describing motion of the vehicle are (5)Mv·z··+∑i=16ki·z+(c(k3+k6)-a(k1+k4) -b(k2+k5))·θ-(d·∑i=13ki-e·∑i=36ki)·α -∑i=16(ki·zik)=0 (6)Iθ·θ··+(c2(k3+k6)+a2(k1+k4)+b2(k2+k5))·θ +(c(k3+k6)-a(k1+k4)-b(k2+k5))·z -(c(d·k3-e·k6)-a(d·k1-e·k4) -b(d·k2-e·k5))·α -c(k3·z3k+k6·z6k)+a(k1·z1k+k4·z4k) +b(k2·z2k+k5·z5k)=0 (7)Iα·α··+(d2·∑i=13ki+e2·∑i=36ki)·α -(d·∑i=13ki+e·∑i=36ki)·z-(c(d·k3-e·k6) -a(d·k1-e·k4)-b(d·k2-e·k5))·θ +d·∑i=13ki-e·∑i=36ki=0 (8)mik·z··ik+(ki+kik)·zik-ki(z+(yv-yi)·θ +(xv-xi)·α+zip)=0,i=1…6

Forces acting on the structure are made up of a static and a dynamic part. Static part represents gravitational force and dynamic part is a contact force, which is the consequence of vehicle and structure motion (9)Pi=Mvg(yi+1-yi-1)(xi+1-xi-1)2BvLv +mikg+kik(zik-zip) The position of each wheel depending on the vehicle speed and time in every time increment can be obtained according to equations (10)y0i=v·ti-(yv-yi)

sec.title: Finite shell strip formulation
sec.p: This method is based on a dimensional reduction, which is realised by the separation of variables, significantly reducing the number of unknowns and the computational effort involved.19 A flat shell strip is formed by combining the plate strip and the plane stress strip such that both bending and in-plane deformations can be simulated. Structural matrices are sparse, the number of unknowns is highly reduced, as well as the computational effort and time.

Bridge is discretised with a flat shell strips in two planes: a plate is divided into seven strips in the horizontal plane and each of the six ribs is modelled with one strip in the vertical plane (Figure 3). Discretisation is made in transverse direction only, such that the length of strip element corresponds to the bridge length. Characteristic matrices can be found in the Appendix 2. For the elements lying in the vertical plane, transformation of force and displacement vector and mass and stiffness matrices is performed between the local and global coordinate system with relative transforms.19 Figure 3.
Finite strip bridge model.

sec.title: Vehicle strip element formulation
sec.p:
Vehicle strip element method is presented for the vehicle discretisation and easier coupling with the structure. The idea was to incorporate moving vehicle into the structure system through this vehicle strip element (Figure 4). Vehicle is discretised with kind of a finite strip, similar to one used for the structure. Vehicle strip coincides with the structure shell strip that is in contact with the vehicle. Thus, all the strip elements and the appropriate characteristic matrices remain unchanged, except those in contact with the vehicle, called the vehicle strip element. Vehicle mass is multiplied by the shape functions and added to a vehicle strip element mass matrix, depending on its position in every instant. Vehicle strip characteristic matrices have the same dimension as the structural ones, because vehicle DOFs are embedded into the structure system. This fact leaves the opportunity to introduce different new conditions into the interaction model quite easily (11)M(t,m)=MvN(x0)N(x0)TΛ(t,m)2 (12)Pi(t,m)=PiN(x0)Λ(t,m) Structure and vehicle dynamic equations are (13)[Ms]·{w··}s+[Ks]·{w}s={F}s (14)[Mv]·{w··}v+[Kv]·{w}v={F}v Conservation of contact between the vehicle and structure is ensured with the equality of contact force (15){Fc}i={ki}·([Nv]{w}v+{zr})+∑i{ki}(yv-yi)·{θ} +∑i{ki}(xv-xi)·{α}-Mvg Figure 4.
Vehicle strip element.

sec.title: Solution procedure
sec.p: When the vehicle model is more realistic, there are more differential equations to solve. In the case of a moving force model, just a plate equation of motion has to be solved. For a five-DOF vehicle model there are six equations, while in the case of a nine-DOF vehicle model, there are 10 differential equations to solve. These additional equations describe vehicle motion in the vertical plane as a separate dynamic system. The structural equation is2 (16)ρh∂2w(x,y,t)∂t2+D(∂4w(x,y,t)∂x4+2∂4w(x,y,t)∂x2∂y2+∂4w(x,y,t)∂y4) =δ(x-ξ)δ(y-v·t)[PM-MVd2(x,y,t)dt2+Fc(t)]

Constant contact between the vehicle and structure is assumed, which is realised through dynamic interaction force Fc(t) between the vehicle and structure, caused by the structure displacement. Additional equations of a vehicle can be written (17)Mv·z··+∑i=1nki·z=Fc(t)

Implicit unconditionally stable time integration is the most effective method in structural dynamic analysis20 in which the system equilibrium at time t+Δt is considered. Impulse acceleration method,8 based on Newmark family of method is used here.21

sec.title: Numerical examples and results
sec.p:
Four examples of practical nature are observed: (a) a simply supported stiffened plate traversed by a five-DOF vehicle; (b) a simply supported stiffened plate traversed by a nine-DOF vehicle; (c) a simply supported plate traversed by a five-DOF vehicle; and (d) a simply supported plate traversed by a nine-DOF vehicle. A stiffened plate is modelled according to the real short span bridge design (Figure 5, Table 1). Vehicle is considered to be a three-axle truck (Tables 2 and 3). Figure 5.
Vehicle and bridge cross-section idealisation. Table 1.

Moving force 4.5·104 – – – – – – – –
Five-DOF model 4.5·104 3 2 3 m1 = 100 m2 = 200 m3 = 50 k1 = 8.5·105 k2 = 7.5·105 k3 = 25·103 k1p = 8.5 k2p = 7.5 k3p = 25 5.67·105 _
Nine-DOF model 4.5·104 3 3 6 m1 = 50 m2 = 100 m3 = 25 m4 = 50 m5 = 100 m6 = 25 k1 = 17·105 k4 = 17·105 k2 = 15·105 k5 = 15·105 k3 = 50·103 k6 = 50·103 k1p = 17 k2p = 15 k3p = 25 k4p = 17 k5p = 15 k6p = 25 5.67·105 4.1·104
DOF: degree of freedom.

Complete bridge-structure interaction model is proposed, with use of a vehicle strip element and a full vehicle model. It is verified by comparison of analytical and numerical solution for a moving constant force on the simply supported plate. A nine-DOF vehicle model as a full vertical vehicle model is compared with a five-DOF vehicle model (Figure 6). Parametric study for the influence of vehicle mass and length, moving velocity and bridge cross-section stiffness is performed. Figure 6.
Maximum deflection in time for v = 30 m/s of: (a) a plate and (b) a stiffened plate.

From the midpoint displacement distribution in time for moving velocity of 30 m/s, shown in Figure 6, one can notice a magnification of dynamic results for a plate, by comparison with a stiffened plate. This dynamic magnification is also present in vertical velocity distribution in time (Figure 7). Reason for this is unrealistic flexibility property of a plate model, which does not characterise the bridge structures in reality. Figure 7.
Vertical bridge: (a) velocity and (b) acceleration for different vehicle models.

When comparing vehicle models, one can see that a five-DOF vehicle model gives higher values for displacement than other two models (a moving force and a nine-DOF vehicle model). A five-DOF vehicle model indicates incorrect value for a critical speed, which is shown in Figure 8(a). Critical speed is a structure, not a vehicle property, which means that all vehicle models should have the same vehicle speed (Figure 9(a)). A five-DOF vehicle model shows almost linear correlation between maximum displacement and change of vehicle mass (Figures 10(a) and 11(a)), while in the case of a nine-DOF model this correlation is nonlinear, for both plate and stiffened plate structure models. Vehicle suspension distance effect is also observed (Figure 12). One can see that longer the vehicle is, lower the maximum displacement value, and the solution moves away from that for a moving force. In Figures 10(a) and 11(a) influence of cross-section stiffness on the maximum displacement is shown. For both plate and a stiffened plate, this relation is nonlinear, but with a quite different trend. Number of axles does not play major role, as long as the truck is observed as a single body. Figure 8.
(a) Maximum stiffened plate displacement versus moving velocity and (b) maximum stiffened plate displacement position versus moving velocity. Figure 9.
(a) Maximum plate displacement versus moving velocity and (b) maximum plate displacement position versus moving velocity.

caption.p: Maximum displacement of a plate versus: (a) vehicle mass and (b) structure cross-section stiffness for different loading models.
Maximum displacement of a stiffened plate versus: (a) vehicle mass and (b) structure cross-section stiffness for different loading models.
Midpoint displacement in time for a variable vehicle length: (a) five-DOF vehicle model and (b) nine-DOF vehicle model. DOF: degree of freedom.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: Based on the idea of the finite strip element, the new vehicle strip element is introduced. Combined with the shell finite strip it enabled observing all DOFs of the structure and the vehicle, reducing modelling and calculation time and effort in the same time. Vehicle strip element for a full vehicle model on a stiffened plate ensures more reliable interaction analysis. A parametric study is made to compare vehicle models with different level of complexity, in order to enquire to what extent simplification of the model affects reliability of the analysis results. The bridge cross-section shape and the stiffness influence is also investigated. Many models and parameters are tested and one can make several conclusions. A plate structure indicates higher dynamic response in comparison with a stiffened plate, because it has natural frequency closer to the frequency of a moving vehicle. With increase of the vehicle mass and vehicle model complexity, importance of the bridge cross-section shape also increases. A nine-DOF vehicle model causes lower dynamic response than a five-DOF model or a moving force model, because it achieves interaction with the structure through the two distant lines, instead of only one line or a point. Thus, suspension distance and mutual interaction is taken into consideration. Suspension distance plays an important role, which is more evident in the nine-DOF model, while the number of axles does not. Bridge behaviour depends more strongly on the suspension mass and distance, than it does on the suspension stiffness. When comparing vehicle models, difference between maximum displacement values is not significant as it is in the maximum displacement distribution in time. A nine-DOF vehicle model generates lower displacement values when vehicle moves along the first half of the span and higher when vehicle moves along the second half. This difference in distribution becomes more evident when distance between vehicle suspension increases. All of these conclusions suggest that in the bridge analysis and design, a full vehicle model as well as the real structure cross section should be applied in order to have detailed and comprehensive model. Such realistic examples of bridge analysis are rare in literature due to the large effort they require using standard finite elements. Proposed vehicle strip element method enables analysis of the vehicle–structure interaction in a greater detail and reduces the number of unknowns and computation time to the great extent. Proposed interaction analysis model comprises all simple vehicle models, such as moving force, moving mass or pitch and bounce vehicle model and can be easily reduced to one of them. Also, any new vehicle or structure condition can be incorporated into the proposed scheme very easily.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This paper is part of the research within the scientific project no. 114-0982562-1460: ‘Long flexible structures’ financially supported by the Croatian Ministry of science, education and sports.

sec.title: Appendix 2

Where [Kijp]mn and [Kijb]mn and [Mijp]mn and [Mijb]mn refer to the in-plane and bending stiffness and mass matrices, respectively.
